item.description:
Resources to learn more about strings, encoding, Unicode…

  • Mastering Ruby - Strings and Encodings - Book by Aaron Lasseigne
  • Guide to string encoding in Ruby - Article by Aaron Patterson
  • Pragmatic Unicode, or How do I stop the pain - Talk by Ned Batchelder at PyCon 2012 (from 2010, still great!)
  • The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Absolutely, Positively Must Know About Unicode and Character Sets (No Excuses!) - Article by Joel Spolsky (from 2003, still great!)
  • The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Must Know About Unicode in 2023 (Still No Excuses!) - Article by Nikita Prokopov

item.title: about
item.description:
üë©üèª‚Äçüíª🐰🕳️ I’m a software engineer who loves writing code, investigating tricky bugs down rabbit holes and helping others above all things. I value curiosity, generosity and humility very highly. I think the three are very closely related.

📚🧮 I have a background in theoretical computer science and I wanted to study pure mathematics. I’ll do it one day.

💬🗺️ I’m a polyglot at heart, trying to be a polyglot on the outside. I love learning programming languages, even in absurd ways, and human languages as well.

item.title: Machines that talk about themselves
item.description:
Sentences and expressions

  • An expression is any combination of the symbols P, N, A, -. For example, NPA‚ÄîP-A.
  • A sentence is an expression with an assigned meaning.

The printing machine üñ®Ô∏è

We’re giving a printing machine, and we call an expression printable if the machine can print it.

  • P-X means “X is printable”
  • NP-X means “X is not printable”

The associate of an expression X is X-X.

  • PA-X means “the associate of X, X-X, is printable”
  • NPA-X means “the associate of X, X-X, is not printable”

A sentence is an expression of the following 4 forms:

Some resources to accompany the talk and learn more:
